content.description: BRICK IS NOT IN. Very fun little problem with some comfy grass behind you if you fall. Top out possible.
content.location: Right of the entrance, around the corner. The concrete pattern in the middle of the brick wall that runs parallel with Spring St.

content.description: Shoes were really helpful. First attempt: GS, 10/21/2021. A high foot to back press leads to a shuffle up until you can reach the jug top out. Then pull up.
content.location: Jump up onto the planting area next to the stairwell in the Southeast corner of the parking lot (closest to Pearson and the psychology building). The boulder problem is the chimney.

content.description: A dihedral (corner) climb with some fairly interesting movements - not just a ladder. Can incorporate a mantle or similar move into the climb. Can chose to top out.
content.location: Just to the left of the main entrance of Pearson. The right side of the dihedral. Check pictures for details.

content.description: Boring ladder. Start on the low roof. Can get up to that "roof" from the direction of the bike rack, or from down below via Di-wall-i. Careful, the floor is slippery at the base of the climb. Top out possible, down climb not fun.
content.location: Northwest corner of Pearson, by the bike rack.

content.description: One move boulder. A muscle-up type mantle with a very high foot. The grade is as hard as it us mostly because of the risk factor. No good spot to put a pad. Potential for another boulder around the corner of this climb, starting on the ground instead of 5 feet up the rock. First attempt: HW and OS, 11/3/2021.
content.location: The two gates right outside the baseball field and parking lot.

content.description: Easy ladder. First ascended on the 3rd of November, 2021 (same date as Diwali, hence the name). This route can lead to the roof where "Moonlight Skate" starts.
content.location: To the left of "Bright Bridge," a wall that leads up to a low roof.

content.description: Ladder up the side of the Pearson, under a little arch. Slight negative crimps all the way up. Can use the corner to make the climb a little more secure. Can climb either side for the same effect. Top-out possible but scary. Tall for a boulder problem.
content.location: West facing side of Pearson, under the triple arch-type structure.

content.description: Climbs north of High Street on Miami University's campus. Most of them are right around Pearson Hall; hopefully, someone will develop more soon.
